channel.title: Comments on: Encountering My First Chess Advocate

item.title: By: Ben Hong
item.dc:creator: Ben Hong
item.description: I think at the time my co-worker was speaking more in terms of the complexities of individual pieces. After thinking about it for some time, I realized that people who haven't played go don't realize that the complexity with go does not lie in single pieces; but the overarching connections and dynamic value that changes as the game progresses.
item.content:encoded: I think at the time my co-worker was speaking more in terms of the complexities of individual pieces. After thinking about it for some time, I realized that people who haven’t played go don’t realize that the complexity with go does not lie in single pieces; but the overarching connections and dynamic value that changes as the game progresses.

item.title: By: Ben Hong
item.dc:creator: Ben Hong
item.description: Amen to that! Go is a strategy game for all to play. Down with 'Eastern mysticism'!
item.content:encoded: Amen to that! Go is a strategy game for all to play. Down with ‘Eastern mysticism’!

item.title: By: grok
item.dc:creator: grok
item.description: One thing I hope for is that Go loses the 'Eastern mysticism' and 'traditionalist' ,angle. It can well stand on its own, post-feudal era.
item.content:encoded: One thing I hope for is that Go loses the ‘Eastern mysticism’ and ‘traditionalist’ ,angle. It can well stand on its own, post-feudal era.

item.title: By: grok
item.dc:creator: grok
item.description: The key is indeed in that the rules themselves are essentially drop-dead simple: but also that the emergent tactical and strategic considerations move FAR beyond that underlying rule-based simplicity. Chess simply cannot compare. It was _made_ more complex long ago, simply to 'jazz it up', AFAIC.
item.content:encoded:
The key is indeed in that the rules themselves are essentially drop-dead simple: but also that the emergent tactical and strategic considerations move FAR beyond that underlying rule-based simplicity.
Chess simply cannot compare. It was _made_ more complex long ago, simply to ‘jazz it up’, AFAIC.

item.title: By: grok
item.dc:creator: grok
item.description: There's no way chess is more complex. But that's overall -- not in the particulars of tactical play: with 6 very different pieces, of different (fixed) number, to consider.
item.content:encoded: There’s no way chess is more complex. But that’s overall — not in the particulars of tactical play: with 6 very different pieces, of different (fixed) number, to consider.

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: I like that proverb. Thanks for sharing that!
item.content:encoded: I like that proverb. Thanks for sharing that!

item.title: By: Gim
item.dc:creator: Gim
item.description: It seems the chinese go proverb, "two siblings shouldn't fight for the same road", and, "winning all the battles can lose the war" are constantly violated in this debate! Two can either beg for the crumbs and put the other down in order to be given more ("Who the heck plays X!", "A is OBVIOUSLY superior to B") or work together (World mind Games).
item.content:encoded:
It seems the chinese go proverb, “two siblings shouldn’t fight for the same road”, and, “winning all the battles can lose the war” are constantly violated in this debate!
Two can either beg for the crumbs and put the other down in order to be given more (“Who the heck plays X!”, “A is OBVIOUSLY superior to B”) or work together (World mind Games).

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Still here Molokai! Just busy off in code world and training myself in other disciplines. It certainly would be fantastic if my training pays off in go as well; but I won't hold my breath! Haha. Interesting question! I believe the basic answer to your question is best represented by trying to live in the corner of the board. Generally speaking, the 3-3 is the guaranteed invasion that will allow life. Beyond that, there are probably some extraneous scenarios where life by ko is possible; but otherwise I imagine it's not possible. Just my small two cents though.
item.content:encoded:
Still here Molokai! Just busy off in code world and training myself in other disciplines. It certainly would be fantastic if my training pays off in go as well; but I won’t hold my breath! Haha.
Interesting question! I believe the basic answer to your question is best represented by trying to live in the corner of the board. Generally speaking, the 3-3 is the guaranteed invasion that will allow life. Beyond that, there are probably some extraneous scenarios where life by ko is possible; but otherwise I imagine it’s not possible. Just my small two cents though.

item.title: By: MolokaiCowboy
item.dc:creator: MolokaiCowboy
item.description: Are you still with us, Master? Studying hard and coming back as 7d? :) I recall Bobby Fischer's 'suddenly I got good' comment when he went from ELO 2103 in July 1957 to 2722 in December 1957. I think that would be equivalent to going from 1d-2d to 7p-8p (chess ratings have inflated apx 200 points in the past 40 years according to some studies). I have a Go question for you also, please: Has any study been done of something like this: Given a fully enclosed area of 'x' empty points - in which areas can the opposing player build a live group? It would seem a computer could do this up to perhaps 20-25 points in any regular or irregular shape fairly easily?
item.content:encoded:
Are you still with us, Master? Studying hard and coming back as 7d? ðŸ™‚ I recall Bobby Fischer’s ‘suddenly I got good’ comment when he went from ELO 2103 in July 1957 to 2722 in December 1957. I think that would be equivalent to going from 1d-2d to 7p-8p (chess ratings have inflated apx 200 points in the past 40 years according to some studies).
I have a Go question for you also, please: Has any study been done of something like this: Given a fully enclosed area of ‘x’ empty points – in which areas can the opposing player build a live group? It would seem a computer could do this up to perhaps 20-25 points in any regular or irregular shape fairly easily?
